title: Can we use pros and cons in formal writing? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll quote Garner, as I do so frequently: “pro and con; pro et con. The latter phrase is the Latin for “for and against.” The English rendering—pro and con—is standard. The phrase may function as a noun <the pros and cons>, as an adverb <people argued pro and con>, or as an adjective <arguments pro and con>.” “Pro and con has also been used as a verb phrase <to pro-and-con the issue>, and although today this use sounds somewhat odd, it has the sanction of long standing: the OED dates it from 1694. The OED also records the phrase as a preposition <arguments pro and con the proposal>, but for and against would be better. Current ratio: 320:1” Excerpt From: Bryan Garner. “Garner's Modern English Usage.” iBooks. ‎Garner's Modern English Usage **** The Google Ngram Viewer shows a recent uptick of “pros and cons” in books, but check out the date on the last data. More than a decade ago.

It depends how informal it is, and what the purpose is of the writing. I would not personally use the phase, or either of the words in formal writing. I prefer the more formal words, ‘advantages and disadvantages’. If the writing is for an essay or other assignment that will be graded, then it would be best to check with the teacher/lecturer/professor concerned to see what words and phrases they consider too informal.
